title: Shari’ah Standard No. (9): Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek

sections.title: 1. Preface
sections.content: This standard outlines the basis of the Shari’ah rulings on Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, beginning with the rules relating to the promise to lease, if any, and concluding with the rules of repossession of the leased property in an operating Ijarah by the lessor or transferring its ownership in case of Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, within or by the end of the lease term. The Standard also aims to outline the Shari’ah requirements that must be observed by Islamic financial Institutions (Institution/Institutions) with respect to Ijarah transactions.

sections.title: 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution
4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah
6. Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables
8. Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek
9. Date of Issuance of the Standard
1. Scope of the Standard
sections.content: This standard covers operating leases of properties or Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, whether the Institution is the lessor or the lessee. This standard does not cover Sukuk al-Ijarah, as they are covered by Shari’ah Standard on Investment Sukuk, nor the employment of persons (labour contract), as it is covered by a separate standard.

sections.title: 2/1 Ijarah contract execution
sections.content: An Ijarah contract is executed for an asset owned by the lessor or an usufruct owned by the sub-lessor. However, it is for a customer to request an Institution to acquire the asset or to acquire the usufruct of an existing asset which the customer wishes to take on lease.

sections.title: 2/2 Master agreement for Ijarah
sections.content: Ijarah may be effected directly on the asset without any requirement of a preceding master agreement. It is permissible to have a master agreement covering a number of Ijarah transactions, setting out general terms and conditions. Separate lease contracts or notices may refer to the terms of the master agreement.

sections.title: 2/3 Payment for seriousness
sections.content: The Institution may require the customer to pay a sum to ensure seriousness, with deductions made in cases proportional to actual damage if the promise is not fulfilled.

sections.title: 2/4 Security deposit handling
sections.content: The money deposited by the customer as a security can be held on trust or on an investment trust basis, allowing the Institution to invest it. It's permissible to agree that this amount may be treated as an advance payment of lease instalments.

sections.title: 3. Acquisition of the Asset to Be Leased, or Its Usufruct, by the Institution
3/1 Requirements for an Ijarah contract
sections.content: For an Ijarah contract concerning a specified asset, the lease contract should be preceded by acquisition of the asset or its usufruct.

sections.title: 3/1/1 Asset ownership by Institution
sections.content: If the asset or its usufruct is owned by the Institution, an Ijarah contract may be executed upon agreement by the parties.

sections.title: 3/1/2 Asset acquisition by customer or third party
sections.content: The Ijarah contract shall not be executed until the Institution has acquired the asset if it is to be acquired by the customer or a third party.

sections.title: 3/2 Leasing to the acquiring party
sections.content: An asset may be acquired by a party and then leased to that party, without stipulating the Ijarah contract as a condition of the purchase contract.

sections.title: 3/3 Sub-lease conditions
sections.content: A lessee may sub-lease an asset to a third party for variable rental amounts unless restricted by the lessor.

sections.title: 3/4 Leasing back to the lessor
sections.content: A lessee may lease the asset back to its owner under certain conditions, avoiding contracts of 'Inah.

sections.title: 3/5 Ijarah for non-owned assets with specifications
sections.content: An Ijarah contract may be executed for an asset promised for delivery with specific conditions, even if not owned by the lessor.

sections.title: 3/6 Joint acquisition and leasing
sections.content: A customer may jointly acquire an asset with the Institution and lease the Institution's share, paying rental proportionate to the share owned.

sections.title: 3/7 Appointing a customer as agent
sections.content: An Institution may appoint a customer as its agent to acquire an asset on its behalf, but it is preferable that the agent not be the prospective lessee.

sections.title: 4. Concluding an Ijarah Contract and the Forms of Ijarah
4/1 Signature of the contract and consequences
sections.content: The lease contract is binding, with defined rules for terminations or alterations. The Ijarah period must be specified, potentially starting at a future date.

sections.title: 4/1/1 Binding nature of the contract
sections.content: The lease contract is binding, cannot be terminated or altered without mutual consent, with some termination provisions.

sections.title: 4/1/2 Duration specification
sections.content: The Ijarah period must be specified, commencing on the execution date unless a future date is agreed.

sections.title: 4/1/3 Lessor's delivery obligations
sections.content: No rental is due if the asset is not delivered by the specified date, with potential lease extensions.

sections.title: 4/1/4 'Arboun (Earnest Money)
sections.content: 'Arboun is treated as an advance rental payment, with specific conditions regarding contract termination.

sections.title: 4/2/1 Successive lease arrangements
sections.content: Ijarah contracts can be executed in succession for the same asset with different lessees, not concurrently.

sections.title: 4/2/2 Restriction during existing Ijarah
sections.content: Lessor cannot sign another Ijarah for the same period or remaining period of an existing Ijarah.

sections.title: 4/2/3 Ijarah with multiple lessees
sections.content: Contracts can be signed with several lessees sharing the same usufruct, with usage time assigned.

sections.title: 4/2/4 Sharing usufruct among lessees
sections.content: A lessee may invite others to share usufruct before sub-leasing, allowing co-ownership in the usufruct.

sections.title: 5/1 Rules governing benefit and leased property
5/1/1 Permissible use of leased assets
sections.content: Leased asset must be usable preserving the asset, and benefit must be Shari’ah-compliant.

sections.title: 5/1/2 Usufruct of undivided assets
sections.content: Subject matter can be a share in an undivided asset, benefiting by agreed means such as time-sharing.

sections.title: 5/1/3 Ijarah with non-Muslims
sections.content: Ijarah may be executed with non-Muslims if the use is permissible.

sections.title: 5/1/4 Suitable use and care
sections.content: Lessee must use the asset suitably, conforming to Shari’ah and avoiding damage.

sections.title: 5/1/5 Lessor's responsibility for defects
sections.content: Lessor bears responsibility for defects impairing intended use, cannot exclude liability for impairment.

sections.title: 5/1/6 Lessee's obligation for misconduct
sections.content: Lessee must repair or restore usufruct impaired by misconduct, without rent waiver during lost benefit.

sections.title: 5/1/7 Maintenance responsibilities
sections.content: Lessor cannot stipulate major maintenance on lessee who can be tasked at lessor's cost, while ordinary maintenance by lessee.

sections.title: 5/1/8 Asset responsibility and insurance
sections.content: Lessor maintains asset responsibility, may insure at own cost, factoring such into rental.

sections.title: 5/2/1 Form of lease rentals
sections.content: Lease rental can be cash, goods, or services, specified either lump sum or not.

sections.title: 5/1/5 Lessor’s responsibility for defects
sections.content: The lessor must accept responsibility for any defects of the leased asset which impair the intended use of the asset, and may not exclude his liability for any impairment that the leased asset may sustain, either by his own doing or as a result of events outside his control, which affect the benefits intended to be available under the Ijarah contract.

sections.title: 5/1/6 Lessee's responsibility for misconduct
sections.content: If the benefit from the leased asset is impaired wholly or partially as a result of the lessee’s misconduct, while the property remains under lease, the lessee is obliged to restore or repair the usufruct, and rent for the time during which the benefit is lost is not to be waived.

sections.title: 5/1/7 Maintenance responsibility
sections.content: The lessor may not stipulate that the lessee will undertake the major maintenance of the asset that is required to keep it in the condition necessary to provide the contractual benefits under the lease. The lessor may delegate to the lessee the task of carrying out such maintenance at the lessor’s cost. The lessee should carry out operating or periodical (ordinary) maintenance.

sections.title: 5/1/8 Lessor’s responsibility for the asset
sections.content: The leased asset is the responsibility of the lessor throughout the duration of the Ijarah, unless the lessee commits misconduct or negligence. The lessor may take out permissible insurance on it whenever possible, and such insurance expenses must be borne by the lessor.

sections.title: 5/2/1 Rental specification
sections.content: The lease rental may be in cash or in kind (goods) or benefit (service). The rental must be specified, either as a lump sum covering the duration of the Ijarah contract, or by instalments for parts of the duration.

sections.title: 5/2/2 Rental obligation commencement
sections.content: The rental is made obligatory by the contract and the lessor’s entitlement to the rental runs from the time when the lessee starts to benefit from the asset or once the lessor makes the usufruct of the asset available to the lessee.

sections.title: 5/2/3 Floating rental conditions
sections.content: In case the rental is subject to changes (floating rental), it is necessary that the amount of the rental of the first period of the Ijarah contract be specified in lump sum.

sections.title: 5/2/4 Rental split
sections.content: It may be agreed that the rental should consist of two specified parts: one to be paid or transferred to the lessor and the other to be held by the lessee to cover any expenses or costs approved by the lessor.

sections.title: 5/2/5 Amendment of future rentals
sections.content: The amendment of future rentals is permissible by the agreement of both parties.

sections.title: 6 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables
6/1 Permissible security
sections.content: Permissible security, of all kinds, may be taken to secure the rental payments or as a security against misuse or negligence on the part of the lessee.

sections.title: 6/2 Advance rental payments
sections.content: The two parties may agree that the rental be paid fully in advance. It is also permissible to make the rent payable in instalments.

sections.title: 6/3 No increase in rental for delayed payment
sections.content: No increase in the rental due may be stipulated by the lessor in case of delay in payment by the lessee.

sections.title: 6/4 Donation for delayed payment
sections.content: It may be provided in the contract that a lessee who delays payment for no good reason undertakes to donate a certain amount or percentage of the rental due in case of late payment.

sections.title: 6/5 Foreclosure of security
sections.content: In case of foreclosure of the security provided by the lessee, the lessor may deduct from such amounts only what is due in respect of rental for previous periods.

sections.title: 7/1 Selling of or damage to the leased asset
7/1/1 Transfer of ownership to lessee
sections.content: If the lessor sells the leased asset to the lessee, the Ijarah contract is terminated due to the transfer of the ownership of the leased asset and ownership of usufruct to the lessee.

sections.title: 7/1/2 Sale to third parties
sections.content: The lessor may sell the leased asset to a third party other than the lessee, and the title to the asset together with the rights and obligations of the lessor under the Ijarah contract is thereby transferred to the new owner.

sections.title: 7/1/3 Total destruction of the leased asset
sections.content: In case of total destruction of the leased asset, the Ijarah contract is terminated if it is concluded on an identified asset.

sections.title: 7/1/4 Lessee’s liability for damage
sections.content: The leased asset in the possession of the lessee is held by the lessee in a fiduciary capacity on behalf of the lessor.

sections.title: 7/1/5 Partial destruction
sections.content: In case of partial destruction of the leased asset in a manner that impairs the benefits expected from the leased asset, the lessee may terminate the Ijarah contract.

sections.title: 7/1/6 Ijarah Mawsufah fi al-Dhimmah and asset replacement
sections.content: In an Ijarah Mawsufah fi al-Dhimmah, the owner in cases of total and partial destruction must offer an alternative asset having a specification similar to that of the destroyed asset.

sections.title: 7/1/7 Stopping use or return of asset
sections.content: If the lessee stops using the leased asset or returns it to the owner without the owner’s consent, the rental will continue to be due.

sections.title: 7/2 Termination, expiry and renewal of the Ijarah contract
7/2/1 Termination by mutual consent
sections.content: It is permissible to terminate the lease contract by mutual consent but it is not permissible for one party to terminate it except in case of force majeure.

sections.title: 7/2/2 Termination for non-payment
sections.content: The lessor may stipulate that the Ijarah contract be terminated if the lessee does not pay the rent or fails to pay it on time.

sections.title: 7/2/3 Ijarah contract continuation upon death
sections.content: An Ijarah contract does not terminate with the death of either party thereto.

sections.title: 7/2/4 Expiry due to asset destruction
sections.content: An Ijarah contract expires with the total destruction of the leased asset in the case of leasing a specific asset.

sections.title: 7/2/5 Pre-commencement termination
sections.content: The two parties may terminate the Ijarah contract before it begins to run.

sections.title: 7/2/6 Lease expiry and renewal
sections.content: The lease expires upon the expiry of its term, but it may remain operative for a good cause, such as the late arrival to the place intended in the lease of transportation vehicles.

sections.title: 8 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Property in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek
8/1 Separate document for transfer
sections.content: In Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, the method of transferring the title in the leased asset to the lessee must be evidenced in a document separate from the Ijarah contract document.

sections.title: 8/2 Binding promise by lessor
sections.content: A promise to transfer the ownership by way of one of the methods specified is a binding promise by the lessor.

sections.title: 8/3 New contract for ownership transfer
sections.content: In all cases of transfer of ownership by way of gift or sale, it is necessary, when the promise is fulfilled, that a new contract be drawn up.

sections.title: 8/4 Contingent gift and payment
sections.content: In case the Ijarah contract is combined, through a separate document, with a gift contingent upon the condition that the remaining rent instalments be paid, the ownership is transferred to the lessee if the condition is fulfilled.

sections.title: 8/5 Avoidance of 'Inah
sections.content: If the leased asset was purchased from the lessee before it was leased back to the lessee, a period of time must have expired to avoid the contract of 'Inah.

sections.title: 8/6 Application of Ijarah rules
sections.content: Subject to item 8/8, the rules governing Ijarah must apply to the Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

sections.title: 8/7 Future sale contract execution
sections.content: Transfer of the ownership cannot be made by executing, along with the Ijarah, a sale contract that will become effective on a future date.

sections.title: 8/8 Adjustment of rental in case of destruction
sections.content: If the leased asset is destroyed or if the continuity of the lease contract becomes impossible, then the rental is adjusted based on the prevailing market value.

sections.title: Adoption of the Standard
sections.content: The Shari'ah standard for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek was adopted by the Shari'ah Board in its meeting No. (4) held on 25–27 Safar 1421 A.H., corresponding to 29–31 May 2000 A.D. In its meeting No. (8) held in Mecca on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H., corresponding to 11–16 May 2002 A.D., the Shari'ah Board readopted a resolution to reformat the Shari'ah rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek in the form of a Shari'ah standard.

sections.title: Appendix (A) Brief History of the Preparation of the Standard
1/1 First Meeting Decision
sections.content: In its meeting No. (1) held on 11 Dhul-Hajjah 1419 A.H., corresponding to 27 February 1999 A.D., the Shari'ah Board decided to give priority to the preparation of the Shari'ah rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

sections.title: 1/2 Fatwa and Arbitration Committee Commission
sections.content: On Tuesday 13 Dhul-Hajjah 1419 A.H., corresponding to 30 March 1999 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee decided to commission a Shari'ah consultant to prepare a juristic study and an exposure draft on the Shari'ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek.

sections.title: 1/3 Exposure Draft Amendments
sections.content: In its meeting held on 13–14 Rajab 1420 A.H., corresponding to 22–23 October 1999 A.D., the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee discussed the exposure draft of the Shari'ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, and asked the consultant to make the amendments in light of the comments made by the members.

sections.title: 1/4 Shari’ah Board Amendments
sections.content: The revised exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules was presented to the Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (3) held in Mecca on 10–15 Ramadan 1420 A.H., corresponding to 18–22 December 1999 A.D. The Shari’ah Board made further amendments to the exposure draft of the Shari’ah Rules and decided that it should be distributed to specialists and interested parties in order to obtain their comments in order to discuss them in a public hearing.

sections.title: 1/5 Public Hearing
sections.content: A public hearing was held in Bahrain on 29–30 Dhul-Hajjah 1421 A.H., corresponding to 4–5 April 2000 A.D. The public hearing was attended by more than 30 participants representing central institutions, accounting firms, Shari’ah scholars, academics and others who are interested in this field.

sections.title: 1/6 Joint Committee Meeting
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standards Committee and the Fatwa and Arbitration Com- mittee held a joint meeting on 21–23 Muharram 1421 A.H., corresponding to 26–28 April 2000 A.D., to discuss the comments made about the Shari’ah Rules.

sections.title: 1/7 Board Approval
sections.content: The Shari’ah Board in its meeting No. (4) held on 25–27 Safar 1421 A.H. corresponding to 29–31 May 2000 A.D., in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah discussed the amendments made by the Shari’ah Studies Committee and the Fatwa and Arbitration Committee, and made the amendments which it considered necessary.

sections.title: 1/8 Standard Formatting
sections.content: In its meeting No. (8) held in Al-Madinah Al-Munawwarah on 28 Safar - 4 Rabi’ I, 1423 A.H. corresponding to 11–16 May 2002 A.D., the Shari’ah Board adopted the reformatting of Shari’ah Rules for Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek in the name of Shari’ah Standard No. (9).

sections.title: 1/9 Review Committee Meeting
sections.content: The Shari’ah Standards Review Committee reviewed the standard in its meeting held in Rabi’ II, 1433 A.H. corresponding to March 2012 A.D., in the State of Qatar, and proposed after deliberation a set of amendments.

sections.title: 1/10 Final Approval Meeting
sections.content: In its meeting No. (39) held in the Kingdom of Bahrain on 13–15 Muharram 1435 A.H., corresponding to 6–8 November 2014 A.D., the Shari’ah Board discussed the proposed amendments submitted by the Shari’ah Standards Review Committee and approved necessary amendments.

sections.title: Appendix B: The Shari’ah Basis for the Standard
1/1 Permissibility of Ijarah and Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek
sections.content: Ijarah derives permissibility from the Qur’an, the Sunnah, consensus of Fuqaha and Ijtihad (reasoning). Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek is a form of Ijarah with a promise by the lessor to transfer ownership at the end of the Ijarah term.

sections.title: 1/2 Differences from Hire-Purchase
sections.content: In hire-purchase, the terms of sale and leasing are applied simultaneously, transferring ownership once the last installment is paid. In permissible Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek, ownership is transferred at the end of the Ijarah term.

sections.title: 1/3 Promise to Lease an Asset
sections.content: The basis for allowing payment requests by a promissor is to confirm the commitment. A Fatwa on Hamish Jiddiyyah (security deposit) in Murabahah is applicable to Ijarah.

sections.title: 1/4 Acquisition of the Asset to be Leased
sections.content: Leasing of an asset not owned by the lessor is prohibited. The basis for allowing leasing back an asset to a previous owner is it doesn’t involve an ’Inah sale.

sections.title: 1/5 Contract of Ijarah
sections.content: The basis for the binding nature of an Ijarah contract is that it involves an exchange of counter-values, supported by the saying of Allah: 'Fulfil (your) obligations...'.

sections.title: 1/6 Subject Matter of Ijarah
sections.content: The leased asset must be usable while preserving its essence. Use in impermissible ways makes the lessor an accomplice in wrongdoing.

sections.title: 1/7 Guarantees and Treatment of Ijarah Receivables
sections.content: Guarantees are permissible to secure performance. Accelerated payment clauses are based on the Prophet's saying: 'Muslims are bound by the conditions they made'.

sections.title: 1/8 Changes to the Ijarah Contract
sections.content: The lessor can sell the leased asset without the lessee's consent, provided it doesn't affect the lessee's usufruct rights.

sections.title: 1/9 Transfer of the Ownership in the Leased Asset in Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek
sections.content: Documents of the lessor’s promise to sell must be separate from the Ijarah contract to ensure no linking of liabilities.

sections.title: 2/1 Ijarah
sections.content: Ijarah means leasing of property under a contract for a specified benefit for a specified period in return for a specified consideration.

sections.title: 2/2 Ijarah Muntahia Bittamleek
sections.content: A form of leasing with a promise by the lessor to transfer ownership to the lessee, either at the end of the period or by stages.
